Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Dynamic models of isolation and admixture for community-scale population genomic inference
Award.AbstractNarration:
The rate at which one can increasingly obtain large amounts of DNA data quickly and easily has far outpaced the rate at which computational performance increases over time (Moore's law). To bridge the gap between this impending flood of data and our ability to analyze it, this research will develop computational tools and models that can accommodate the complexity inherent in analyzing genomic data at the level of multiple individuals across different species. This will allow answering long-standing and previously intractable questions about how communities of species form, what creates biodiversity, and how groups of species respond to climate change. The modeling and tool development will focus on the cyclical history of climate change that dominated the Earth for the last two million years with an emphasis on how the resulting cycles of species habitat retraction, expansion and extinction shape the genomic patterns of whole communities.

The impending flood of genomic data will also transform society with the increasing availability of personal genomics kits. To anticipate how the public will increasingly become de facto scientific participants through personal genomics, the research will demonstrate the power, complexities and cautions of population genomic inference as applied to humans by implementing a genomic participant-based human population genomics course and three public events. Participants will optionally obtain vast amounts of non-medically relevant genomic data from themselves and this experiential component will enable communicating to the public about a wide array of complex issues relevant to medicine, history, evolution, ethics, statistics and information literacy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary aim of the funded NSF project “CAREER: Dynamic models of isolation and admixture for community-scale population genomic inference” were to develop tools that enable inference of complex evolutionary histories of cyclical isolation and admixture with whole genome sequences sampled from populations of any species. Beyond the inference of a single species history, a secondary aim was to extend such methods to enable testing models of ecological community assembly. This research successfully led to several novel methods that have been deployed on datasets ranging from whole genomes from isolated populations of orangutans, as well as genome-wide population genetic data from co-distributed assemblages of plants, lizards, birds, snakes, and lampreys. Beyond these methods for comparative population genomic data, the project also yielded a mechanistic modeling framework that enables joint prediction and inference of multiple biodiversity metrics that include community-wide abundances, genetic diversities, and trait distributions. This new generative modeling framework that uses supervised machine learning and high-throughput ecological survey data, has promise to bring together causative processes underlying the tsunami of multi-dimensional biodiversity data, all within a population genetic mechanistic framework. 

The outreach and educational component of this project led to an experiential population genomics course that has been run three times as well as a public NYC Genetic Ancestry Event held at the American Museum of Natural History. The goal of the undergraduate course is to explore how genes can inform about human history, ancestry and evolution while allowing students the option to participate by collecting genetic data from their own genome (using a direct to consumer genomic service such as 23andMe or Ancestry). We now have the ability to cheaply and quickly obtain large amounts of DNA sequence data and already a good portion of the general public is drowning in their own (and/or their biological relatives’) genomic data with little knowledge about how to interpret it, manage it, and protect it. Therefore an added goal of the course is practical whereby students learn bioinformatics skills for handling and analyzing human population genetic data (as well as learn about the history of their own ancestors). The genetic data collected from students who volunteer (the normal fee was waived) also personalizes the concepts in genetics, human history, anthropology, ethics, bioinformatics, quantitative reasoning and information literacy. ​​
